0.paragraph: Describe the location of the excavation site at 20-30 Bourke Street, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.

page_content='Appendix B – Trench Reports 

20-30 Bourke Street (H7822-1548) – Trench Reports 

Introduction 

Preamble 

The VHI site (H7822-1548) at 20-30 Bourke St, Melbourne was excavated across two adjoining areas: 
Area 1 – located in the main building site; and the Easement – located to the west of the theatre building. 

The trench reports, outlined below, detail the excavation of each area separately, with a focus on the 
five occupational phases that were identified at the site. These phases are described in depth in Section 
4.2  of  the  Excavation  Report.  Where  applicable,  specific  built  features  within  a  given  phase  will  be 
described separately as a whole structure. Contexts will be described from the bottom up – natural B, 
A2, or A horizon (whichever was the base level reached during excavation), up to the modern demolition 
and  surface  layers  that  were  removed  for  the  historic  archaeological  excavation  and  salvage  to 
commence.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='into 

to 

Based on this assessment, the site at 20-30 Bourke Street Melbourne (H7822-1548) is deemed to be 
of low to moderate local aesthetic, historical, social and archaeological significance to Melbourne and 
Victoria.

page_content='Ochre Imprints Pty Ltd 

iii 

 
    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0c20-30 Bourke Street, Melbourne (H7822-1548) - Historical Archaeological Salvage Excavation Report Volume 1 

Executive Summary 

This  report  outlines  the  results  of  an  archaeological  excavation  undertaken  at  Victorian  Heritage 
Inventory site H7822-1548, Victoria (Figure 1). The site, located at 20-30 Bourke Street, Melbourne, 
Victoria,  at  the  eastern  end  of  Bourke  Street  near  the  corner  of  Spring  Street,  currently  houses  the 
façade  of  the  Palace  Theatre  building  built  in  1912.  This  building  is  listed  on  the  City  of  Melbourne 
Heritage Overlay (HO500) and is classified by the National Trust (Victorian Heritage database online).' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='Prior to commencement of the archaeological excavation in the Easement, seven exploratory cuts had 
been excavated and subsequently backfilled along the western and eastern sides of the area by the 
demolition and construction team. As part of the archaeological recording, these cuts were assigned 
Trench numbers ranging from numbers 1 – 7 (Figures 27, see Figures 27, 53 & 54 for trench locations 
in the north, middle and south of the Easement)). Trenches 1 and 2 were manually re-excavated by the 
archaeology team to their natural base, allowing a snapshot of the stratigraphy across the northern end 
of the site prior to open excavation commencing. The profile demonstrated that a series of filling events 
had  occurred  post  demolition  of  the  two-storey  structure  that  was  built  c.1850  at  the  property  at  30 
Bourke  Street.  The  remaining  five  trenches  were  consolidated  into  the  open  area  excavation  of  the' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

1.paragraph: The excavation site was located at the corner of Swanston and Franklin streets in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.
source:
page_content='This project report has been structured in two Volumes. Volume 1 details the historical archaeological 
excavation program, while Volume 2 presents the results of the artefact analysis.  

The main body of this report (Volume 1) details the results of the archaeological salvage excavation 
program. An introduction contains the project background information which is followed by the aims 
and  methodology  that  framed  the  approach  to  the  excavation.  A  brief  historical  context  is  provided 
followed by a more detailed site-specific history which precedes the archaeological results section. The 
results section is presented by stratigraphic phase, beginning from the earliest phase of site formation. 
Historical and archaeological evidence including artefact details are integrated in order to synthesise 
the varied data and provide an overall interpretation of the site and its development, as required by 
Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='Appendix B – Trench Reports 

20-30 Bourke Street (H7822-1548) – Trench Reports 

Introduction 

Preamble 

The VHI site (H7822-1548) at 20-30 Bourke St, Melbourne was excavated across two adjoining areas: 
Area 1 – located in the main building site; and the Easement – located to the west of the theatre building. 

The trench reports, outlined below, detail the excavation of each area separately, with a focus on the 
five occupational phases that were identified at the site. These phases are described in depth in Section 
4.2  of  the  Excavation  Report.  Where  applicable,  specific  built  features  within  a  given  phase  will  be 
described separately as a whole structure. Contexts will be described from the bottom up – natural B, 
A2, or A horizon (whichever was the base level reached during excavation), up to the modern demolition 
and  surface  layers  that  were  removed  for  the  historic  archaeological  excavation  and  salvage  to 
commence.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='Jodi Turnbull 

Mechanical Excavator  

Excavator Operator 

Luke Wallis 

Artefact Management  

Artefact Manager 

Jen Porter (with assistance from Amalia 
Carroll) 

Conservator 

Susie Collis 

The  results  of  the  archaeology  program  are  detailed  in  this  report  following  Heritage  Victoria’s 
Guidelines for Investigating Historical Archaeological Artefacts and Sites (July 2015). A requirement of 
the  Guidelines  is  to  develop  a  research  design  during  the  assessment  stage  of  a  project  which  will 
inform the results. The research design is presented following and was considered throughout the report. 

Site Recording 

2.1.1  Area Designations' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='The field investigation program involved a targeted excavation at the following locations (see Figure 2):  

•  The footprint of the former Palace Theatre between the areas of the two basements at the front 

and rear of the property (Area 1): an area of approximately 18m x 25m; 

•  The Easement: an elongated area of approximately 5m x 30m to the west of the former Palace 

Theatre. 

The  monitoring,  investigation  and  salvage  excavation  program  involved  the  uncovering  and 
investigation of archaeological deposits within the areas of archaeological potential (Figures 12 & 13). 
Its main aim was to determine the depth of deposit and level of archaeological integrity at the site in 
compliance with the conditions outlined in the Consent to Damage in advance of ground disturbance 
works commencing at the site. At the conclusion of the archaeological works, notification was given to 
HV that the archaeological work on site had now been completed. 

Excavation Methodology' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

2.paragraph: Example: The Bourke Street archaeological site is located in the heart of Melbourne’s CBD area, at the corner of Bourke and Spring Streets.

excavation program, while Volume 2 presents the results of the artefact analysis.  

The main body of this report (Volume 1) details the results of the archaeological salvage excavation 
program. An introduction contains the project background information which is followed by the aims 
and  methodology  that  framed  the  approach  to  the  excavation.  A  brief  historical  context  is  provided 
followed by a more detailed site-specific history which precedes the archaeological results section. The 
results section is presented by stratigraphic phase, beginning from the earliest phase of site formation.

the varied data and provide an overall interpretation of the site and its development, as required by

page_content='12.  The  report  must  address  the  requirements  of  Heritage  Victoria’s  Guidelines  for  Investigating 
Historical Archaeological Artefacts and Sites (July 2015), and be to the satisfaction of the Executive 
Director, Heritage Victoria. The report must include (but is not limited to) project records, synthesis of 
findings  and  results;  results  of  background  historical  research;  plans  and  images,  addressing  of 
Research Framework, artefact catalogue and analysis, details of artefact conservation and production 
of revised Statements of Significance for both the site and any recovered artefact assemblage.  

This  Project  Report  has  been  prepared  in  compliance  with  Conditions  11  and  12  of  C1512  and  in 
accordance with the Heritage Victoria’s Guidelines for Investigating Historical Archaeological Artefacts 
and Sites (July 2015).

Site Recording 

2.1.1  Area Designations' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='Descriptive questions 

•  What is the nature of the archaeological remains of the Bourke Street archaeological site? 
•  What is the nature of the archaeological record and preservation near Melbourne’s CBD area? 
•  What  natural  and  cultural  taphonomic  processes  have  contributed  to  the  Bourke  Street 

archaeological site and its associated deposits? 

•  What stratigraphic sequences are represented at the Bourke Street archaeological area? 
•  What evidence is there for rubbish and sewage disposal on the Bourke Street archaeological 

area? Are there preserved cesspits or rubbish pits?  

•  How  many  artefact  fragments  were  recovered  from  the  excavation  of  the  Bourke  Street 

archaeological site? 

•  What types and quantities of major artefact groups were recovered? 

Analytical & Interpretive 

•  How  were  artefacts  distributed  spatially  within  the  Bourke  Street  archaeological  site?  Were 

there any particular concentrations of artefacts?' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

3.paragraph: The excavation site is located in Melbourne City Centre, specifically at 20-30 Bourke Street.
source:
page_content='Appendix B – Trench Reports 

20-30 Bourke Street (H7822-1548) – Trench Reports 

Introduction 

Preamble 

The VHI site (H7822-1548) at 20-30 Bourke St, Melbourne was excavated across two adjoining areas: 
Area 1 – located in the main building site; and the Easement – located to the west of the theatre building. 

The trench reports, outlined below, detail the excavation of each area separately, with a focus on the 
five occupational phases that were identified at the site. These phases are described in depth in Section 
4.2  of  the  Excavation  Report.  Where  applicable,  specific  built  features  within  a  given  phase  will  be 
described separately as a whole structure. Contexts will be described from the bottom up – natural B, 
A2, or A horizon (whichever was the base level reached during excavation), up to the modern demolition 
and  surface  layers  that  were  removed  for  the  historic  archaeological  excavation  and  salvage  to 
commence.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='The  archaeological  remains,  although  having  undergone  a  degree  if  disturbance,  are  substantial 
enough to answer key research questions, and to be of value to future researchers.  
The artefact assemblage recovered as part of the investigation and monitoring program may provide 
future opportunities for further investigations into those running and frequenting hotels on the fringes of 
Melbourne ‘s CBD in the second half of the nineteenth century.   

How is it significant? 
The 20-30 Bourke Street site is significant for its intact and preserved archaeological deposits that have 
the capacity to inform on both the working- and middle-class lifestyles within the CBD area of Melbourne 
at this time.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='Analytical & Interpretive 

•  How  were  artefacts  distributed  spatially  within  the  Bourke  Street  archaeological  site?  Were 

there any particular concentrations of artefacts? 

•  Do  archaeological  deposits  and  associated  material  culture  reflect  the  nature  of  mid-to-late 

nineteenth century commercial and residential occupation in Melbourne’s CBD? 

•  What can the recovered material culture reveal about life in the ‘fringe’ of Melbourne’s CBD? 
•  Are deposits spatially distinct and does this correlate to any particular function or uses of the 

• 

space (commercial or residential)? 
Is  there  comparable  data  that  can  be  interpreted  to  make  meaningful  statements  about  the 
differences or similarities to similar sites in Victoria and interstate?' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/20-30 Bourke Street Hist Arch Report - Vol 1 Excavation_finalHV.pdf'}

page_content='into 

to 

Based on this assessment, the site at 20-30 Bourke Street Melbourne (H7822-1548) is deemed to be 
of low to moderate local aesthetic, historical, social and archaeological significance to Melbourne and 
Victoria.
